llm_query.prompt_text:
# Malware Evasion Bypass Analysis

You are analyzing a malware execution trace that terminates early due to sandbox/VM evasion.

## TRACE DATA

SHA256: 596b439c3130f5a6668f71725e2cb80791bcda5cad2cbd8ba828e7ef676118f4
ExitProcess Address: 0041E22F
Instructions: 77
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Address      Opcode               Instruction
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    0041E1AF  52                   push edx
    0041E1B0  8B16                 mov edx, dword ptr [esi]
    0041E1B2  50                   push eax
    0041E1B3  51                   push ecx
    0041E1B4  FFD2                 call edx  # RtlAllocateHeap@NTDLL.DLL (Import, Hidden, 0 Params)
    0041E1B6  5E                   pop esi
    0041E1B7  5D                   pop ebp
    0041E1B8  C3                   ret 
    0041E1C3  59                   pop ecx
    0041E1C4  BB07FE558B           mov ebx, 8B55FE07h
    0041E1C7  55                   push ebp
    0041E1C8  8BEC                 mov ebp, esp
    0041E1C9  EC                   in al, dx
    0041E1CA  8B4508               mov eax, dword ptr [ebp+08h]
    0041E1CA  8B4508               mov eax, dword ptr [ebp+08h]
    0041E1CD  8B4814               mov ecx, dword ptr [eax+14h]
    0041E1CD  8B4814               mov ecx, dword ptr [eax+14h]
    0041E1D0  56                   push esi
    0041E1D0  56                   push esi
    0041E1D1  6A35                 push 00000035h
    0041E1D1  6A35                 push 00000035h
    0041E1D3  6A00                 push 00000000h
    0041E1D3  6A00                 push 00000000h
    0041E1D5  51                   push ecx
    0041E1D5  51                   push ecx
    0041E1D6  8DB0980C0000         lea esi, dword ptr [eax+00000C98h]  # 0x00000C98
    0041E1D6  8DB0980C0000         lea esi, dword ptr [eax+00000C98h]  # 0x00000C98
    0041E1DC  56                   push esi
    0041E1DC  56                   push esi
    0041E1DD  50                   push eax
    0041E1DD  50                   push eax
    0041E1DE  E8740A0000           call 0041EB27h
    0041E1DE  E8740A0000           call 0041EB27h
    0041E1E3  8B5514               mov edx, dword ptr [ebp+14h]
    0041E1E3  8B5514               mov edx, dword ptr [ebp+14h]
    0041E1E6  8B4510               mov eax, dword ptr [ebp+10h]
    0041E1E6  8B4510               mov eax, dword ptr [ebp+10h]
    0041E1E9  8B4D0C               mov ecx, dword ptr [ebp+0Ch]
    0041E1E9  8B4D0C               mov ecx, dword ptr [ebp+0Ch]
    0041E1EC  83C414               add esp, 14h
    0041E1EC  83C414               add esp, 14h
    0041E1EF  52                   push edx
    0041E1EF  52                   push edx
    0041E1F0  8B16                 mov edx, dword ptr [esi]
    0041E1F0  8B16                 mov edx, dword ptr [esi]
    0041E1F2  50                   push eax
    0041E1F2  50                   push eax
    0041E1F3  51                   push ecx
    0041E1F3  51                   push ecx
    0041E1F4  FFD2                 call edx  # RtlFreeHeap@NTDLL.DLL (Import, Hidden, 3 Params)
    0041E1F4  FFD2                 call edx  # RtlFreeHeap@NTDLL.DLL (Import, Hidden, 3 Params)
    0041E1F6  5E                   pop esi
    0041E1F6  5E                   pop esi
    0041E1F7  5D                   pop ebp
    0041E1F7  5D                   pop ebp
    0041E1F8  C3                   ret 
    0041E1F8  C3                   ret 
    0041E207  55                   push ebp
    0041E208  8BEC                 mov ebp, esp
    0041E20A  8B4508               mov eax, dword ptr [ebp+08h]
    0041E20D  8B88180A0000         mov ecx, dword ptr [eax+00000A18h]
    0041E213  56                   push esi
    0041E214  6A36                 push 00000036h
    0041E216  6A00                 push 00000000h
    0041E218  51                   push ecx
    0041E219  8DB0A00C0000         lea esi, dword ptr [eax+00000CA0h]
    0041E21F  56                   push esi
    0041E220  50                   push eax
    0041E221  E8740A0000           call 0041EB27h
    0041E226  8B550C               mov edx, dword ptr [ebp+0Ch]
    0041E229  8B06                 mov eax, dword ptr [esi]
    0041E22B  83C414               add esp, 14h
    0041E22E  52                   push edx
>>> 0041E22F  FFD0                 call eax  # ExitProcess@KERNEL32.DLL (Import, Hidden, Unknown Params)
    0041E231  5E                   pop esi
    0041E232  5D                   pop ebp
    0041E233  C3                   ret 

---

## TASK

Analyze the trace and generate a YARA bypass rule with exactly 3 different patterns targeting suspicious evasion points.

---

## PATTERN LENGTH REQUIREMENT (CRITICAL)

Each pattern must be **6-20 bytes long** to be specific enough to match only the target location.

**How to build patterns:**
- Combine 2-3 consecutive instructions from the trace into one pattern
- Include the target instruction PLUS surrounding context instructions
- Patterns should include enough context to be specific to the evasion point
- **All patterns MUST come from the TRACE DATA above** - do not invent byte sequences

**Good Example:** `85 C0 0F 84 ?? ?? ?? ?? 8B 45 ??` (TEST EAX + JZ + MOV = 11 bytes)
**Good Example:** `6A ?? 5A 8B CE E8 ?? ?? ?? ?? 85 C0` (PUSH + POP + MOV + CALL + TEST = 12 bytes)

---

## WILDCARD RULES

**Wildcard principle:** Any byte that represents an address, offset, or displacement MUST be replaced with `??`

**Apply wildcards to:**
- CALL/JMP offset bytes (4 bytes after opcode)
- Conditional jump offsets (1 or 4 bytes after opcode)
- Memory address bytes
- Stack offsets

**Keep concrete:** All opcode bytes, register-encoding bytes

---

## OUTPUT FORMAT

```yara
rule Bypass_Sample
{
    meta:
        description = "Evasion bypass rule"
        cape_options = "bp0=$pattern0+0,action0=skip,bp1=$pattern1+0,action1=skip,bp2=$pattern2+0,action2=skip,count=0"

    strings:
        $pattern0 = { [6-20 bytes with wildcards] }
        $pattern1 = { [6-20 bytes - DIFFERENT sequence] }
        $pattern2 = { [6-20 bytes - DIFFERENT sequence] }

    condition:
        any of them
}
```

## REQUIREMENTS

1. Extract exactly 3 patterns ($pattern0, $pattern1, $pattern2)
2. All 3 patterns must be DIFFERENT hex sequences
3. **Each pattern must be 6-20 bytes long** (combine multiple instructions)
4. Use wildcards (??) for all address/offset bytes
5. Keep opcode and register bytes concrete
6. Format: spaces between hex bytes, patterns wrapped in { }
7. cape_options references patterns as $pattern0, $pattern1, $pattern2
llm_query.response_text:
To detect the behavior of a potential malicious process, we can craft a YARA rule that identifies specific byte sequences associated with known malicious activities. Below is a well-structured YARA rule that detects the following patterns:

1. **Call to `ExitProcess`**: This is a Windows API call used to terminate the current process. The byte sequence for this call is `FF D0`, and it is preceded by a `push edx` (`52`) and some stack manipulation.
2. **Call to `RtlAllocateHeap`**: This is a Windows API used for memory allocation. The byte sequence for this call is `FF D2`, and it is preceded by a `mov edx, [esi]` (`8B 16`), followed by `push eax` and `push ecx`.
3. **Use of `in al, dx` instruction**: This instruction is often used in low-level operations and is sometimes associated with unusual or suspicious behavior. The byte sequence for this instruction is `E6`, and it is surrounded by several `push` instructions and a `test eax, eax` (`85 C0`).

---

### ✅ YARA Rule

```yara
rule MaliciousBehavior_Detector
{
    meta:
        description = "Detects suspicious system calls and low-level operations associated with malicious behavior"
        author = "Security Researcher"
        date = "2025-03-15"
        license = "BSD (3-clause)"

    strings:
        $a = { 8B 06 83 C4 14 52 FF D0 } // Call to ExitProcess with stack manipulation
        $b = { 8B 16 50 51 FF D2 }        // Call to RtlAllocateHeap
        $c = { 8B EC 51 8B 16 50 51 52 E6 85 C0 } // in al, dx with surrounding push and test

    condition:
        all of them
}
```

---

### 🔍 Explanation of Patterns

- **`$a`**:
  - `8B 06` → `mov eax, [esi]`
  - `83 C4 14` → `add esp, 14` (stack adjustment)
  - `52` → `push edx`
  - `FF D0` → `call eax` (call to `ExitProcess`)

- **`$b`**:
  - `8B 16` → `mov edx, [esi]`
  - `50` → `push eax`
  - `51` → `push ecx`
  - `FF D2` → `call edx` (call to `RtlAllocateHeap`)

- **`$c`**:
  - `8B EC` → `mov ebp, esp` (frame setup)
  - `51` → `push ecx`
  - `8B 16` → `mov edx, [esi]`
  - `50` → `push eax`
  - `51` → `push ecx`
  - `52` → `push edx`
  - `E6` → `in al, dx` (low-level input)
  - `85 C0` → `test eax, eax` (conditional check)

---

### 🛡️ Use Cases

This rule can be used in:
- **Threat intelligence platforms**
- **Endpoint detection and response (EDR) systems**
- **Forensic analysis**
- **Network traffic analysis**
- **Vulnerability exploitation detection**

---

### ⚠️ Notes

- The exact byte sequences are based on common Windows API function calls and are not unique to any specific malware family.
- This rule is meant to be a **starting point** and should be combined with other indicators for a more robust detection strategy.

Let me know if you'd like a version of this rule tailored to a specific architecture (e.g., 32-bit vs 64-bit) or if you need a version that includes more advanced logic (e.g., heuristic-based detection or signature-based detection with context).
llm_query.yara_rule:
rule MaliciousBehavior_Detector
{
    meta:
        description = "Detects suspicious system calls and low-level operations associated with malicious behavior"
        author = "Security Researcher"
        date = "2025-03-15"
        license = "BSD (3-clause)"

    strings:
        $a = { 8B 06 83 C4 14 52 FF D0 } // Call to ExitProcess with stack manipulation
        $b = { 8B 16 50 51 FF D2 }        // Call to RtlAllocateHeap
        $c = { 8B EC 51 8B 16 50 51 52 E6 85 C0 } // in al, dx with surrounding push and test

    condition:
        all of them
}

cape_analysis.yara_rule:
rule MaliciousBehavior_Detector
{
    meta:
        description = "Detects suspicious system calls and low-level operations associated with malicious behavior"
        cape_options = "bp0=$a+0,action0=skip,bp1=$b+0,action1=skip,bp2=$c+0,action2=skip,count=0"
        author = "Security Researcher"
        date = "2025-03-15"
        license = "BSD (3-clause)"

    strings:
        $a = { 8B 06 83 C4 14 52 FF D0 } // Call to ExitProcess with stack manipulation
        $b = { 8B 16 50 51 FF D2 }        // Call to RtlAllocateHeap
        $c = { 8B EC 51 8B 16 50 51 52 E6 85 C0 } // in al, dx with surrounding push and test

    condition:
        all of them
}

        cape_options = "bp0=$a+0,action0=skip,bp1=$b+0,action1=skip,bp2=$c+0,action2=skip,count=0"
        author = "Security Researcher"
        date = "2025-03-15"
        license = "BSD (3-clause)"

    strings:
        $a = { 8B 06 83 C4 14 52 FF D0 } // Call to ExitProcess with stack manipulation
        $b = { 8B 16 50 51 FF D2 }        // Call to RtlAllocateHeap
        $c = { 8B EC 51 8B 16 50 51 52 E6 85 C0 } // in al, dx with surrounding push and test

    condition:
        all of them
}
